definitions: cause someone to feel worried, disappointed, or unhappy about something
knock or push something over so it falls or spills
interfere with the normal arrangement or functioning of something
examples: The bad news really upset her for several days
Don't let his harsh comments upset you too much
The cat jumped on the table and upset the vase
Strong winds upset several market stalls during the storm
The new regulations completely upset our production schedule
Heavy rain upset the tournament's carefully planned timetable

definitions: try earnestly or persistently to persuade someone to do something
experience a strong impulse or desire to do something
examples: The doctor urged him to quit smoking immediately
Parents urged their children to study harder for exams
She felt an overwhelming urge to laugh during the meeting
He resisted the urge to check his phone constantly

definitions: pass urine from the body through the urinary system
examples: The patient needs to urinate frequently due to medication
Dogs typically urinate to mark their territory outdoors

definitions: take, hold, or deploy something as a means of accomplishing a purpose
consume or expend a resource in the process of doing something
take unfair advantage of someone for personal benefit
examples: She uses a special software to edit her photographs
Please use the side entrance during construction work
This old car uses too much fuel for long trips
The factory uses renewable energy for all its operations
He felt his boss was using him for menial tasks
Don't let people use you for their own gain

definitions: show someone to their seat, especially in a theater or ceremony
cause or mark the start of something new or different
examples: The attendant ushered guests to their reserved seats
Young volunteers ushered people into the concert hall
The invention of smartphones ushered in a new digital era
His leadership ushered the company into international markets

definitions: take a position of power or importance illegally or by force
examples: The military general attempted to usurp the president's authority
She accused her deputy of trying to usurp her position

definitions: make practical and effective use of something, especially a resource
examples: The company utilizes advanced technology to improve efficiency
Teachers should utilize various methods to engage different learners

definitions: make a sound with one's voice or speak words aloud
used as emphasis to mean complete or absolute
examples: She didn't utter a single word during the meeting
He uttered a deep sigh of relief after the exam
The project was an utter failure from the beginning
They watched in utter amazement as the performer continued

definitions: leave a place that one previously occupied, making it available
cancel or annul a judgment, conviction, or legal proceeding
examples: Tenants must vacate the apartment by the end of month
Guests should vacate their rooms by noon on checkout day
The judge decided to vacate the previous court ruling
The appeals court vacated the lower court's decision yesterday

definitions: take a holiday or break from work or regular activities
examples: They vacation in Florida every winter to escape cold
Many families vacation together during the summer school break

definitions: treat with a vaccine to produce immunity against a disease
examples: The clinic vaccinated all children against measles last month
Veterinarians recommend vaccinating pets annually for optimal health

definitions: clean carpets or floors using a vacuum cleaner machine
remove air or matter from a space creating partial vacuum
examples: She vacuums the living room carpet twice every week
The cleaning service vacuumed all office floors last night
Scientists vacuum the chamber before beginning the experiment
The technician vacuumed air from the sealed container carefully

definitions: park customers' cars as a professional service at establishments
act as a personal attendant, especially regarding clothing and appearance
examples: The restaurant staff will valet your car for free tonight
Hotels often valet cars for their guests upon arrival
He valeted for wealthy businessmen at the exclusive club
The butler valeted for the duke every morning routinely

definitions: check or prove the validity or accuracy of something
make or declare something legally valid or officially acceptable
examples: Scientists must validate their findings through repeated experiments
The system validates user credentials before granting access
The court validated the election results despite multiple challenges
You need to validate your parking ticket at reception

definitions: assess the monetary worth of something through appraisal or calculation
consider someone or something to be important or beneficial
examples: The appraiser will value your house for insurance purposes
Experts value the painting at over two million dollars
She deeply values honesty in all her personal relationships
Employees value companies that offer flexible working arrangements

definitions: play simple musical accompaniment or improvise while waiting to perform
use sexual attractiveness to seduce or manipulate someone deliberately
examples: The pianist vamped while waiting for the singer to begin
Jazz musicians often vamp between the composed sections freely
She vamped the wealthy businessman at the charity gala
The actress vamped her way through the dramatic scene

definitions: disappear suddenly and completely from sight or from existence
gradually cease to exist or be in use over time
examples: The magician made the rabbit vanish before our eyes
The fog vanished when the morning sun appeared brightly
Ancient civilizations vanished leaving only ruins behind them
Many traditional crafts have vanished in modern industrial society

definitions: defeat thoroughly in a battle, competition, or conflict situation
examples: The army vanquished their enemies in the decisive battle
She vanquished all opponents to win the championship title

definitions: inhale and exhale vapor produced by an electronic cigarette device
examples: Many former smokers now vape instead of smoking cigarettes
Teenagers often vape flavored liquids despite health warnings nationwide

definitions: apply varnish to wood or other surfaces for protection and shine
disguise or gloss over something with a deceptively attractive appearance
examples: He carefully varnished the wooden table to protect the surface
The carpenter varnished all the furniture before delivery yesterday
Politicians often varnish the truth to appeal to voters
She varnished her mistakes with elaborate excuses and explanations

definitions: differ in size, amount, degree, or nature from something else
introduce modifications or changes to something to add variety
examples: Prices vary considerably between different stores in the city
Student performance varies according to their background and preparation
Teachers should vary their methods to maintain student engagement
The chef varies the menu seasonally using local ingredients

definitions: jump over something using hands or a pole for support
store valuables in a secure vault or strongroom for protection
examples: The athlete vaulted over the high bar with ease
She vaulted the fence to retrieve her lost ball
Banks vault precious metals and important documents for clients
The museum vaults priceless artifacts in underground storage rooms

definitions: change direction suddenly, especially to avoid collision or danger
examples: The car veered sharply to avoid hitting the deer
The conversation veered into uncomfortable political topics unexpectedly

definitions: cover the head or face with a veil garment
conceal, disguise, or obscure something from clear view or understanding
examples: The bride veiled her face during the traditional ceremony
Women veiled themselves when entering the sacred temple
Fog veiled the mountain peaks throughout the early morning
He veiled his true intentions behind friendly conversation

definitions: cover something with a thin decorative layer of fine wood or material
examples: The carpenter veneered the cheap wood with expensive mahogany
They veneered the old furniture to give it new life

definitions: regard with great respect, reverence, or devotional honor typically given to sacred things
examples: Many cultures venerate their ancestors through special rituals annually
The community venerates the founding fathers of their nation

definitions: provide an outlet for air, gas, or liquid to escape
give free expression to strong emotions, especially anger or frustration
examples: The system vents excess steam through the safety valve
You need to vent the dryer to the outside properly
She vented her frustration to her best friend yesterday
He vents his anger by going to the gym regularly

definitions: undertake a risky or daring journey or course of action
dare to say something that might be considered presumptuous
examples: They ventured into the unknown territory without proper guides
Few companies venture into such competitive markets these days
May I venture to suggest an alternative approach here?
She ventured an opinion despite her limited experience

definitions: be very close to or on the border of a particular state or condition
examples: The company verges on bankruptcy after years of losses
His behavior verges on the obsessive regarding personal cleanliness

definitions: make sure or demonstrate that something is true, accurate, or justified
examples: Please verify your email address to complete the registration
Investigators must verify all witness statements before proceeding further

definitions: write verse or poetry as a creative literary expression
instruct or make someone thoroughly knowledgeable about something
examples: She verses her feelings in beautiful sonnets every evening
The poet versed his experiences into memorable lyrical works
The mentor versed her students in classical literature comprehensively
He was well versed in ancient philosophical traditions

definitions: confer or bestow power, authority, property, or rights officially
dress in ceremonial or official robes, especially religious vestments
examples: The constitution vests executive power in the president alone
The court vested custody rights with the children's mother
The priest vested himself before conducting the morning service
Judges vest in formal robes before entering the courtroom

definitions: make a careful and critical examination of something or someone
provide medical treatment to animals as a veterinary professional
examples: The committee must vet all candidates before final selection
Security personnel thoroughly vet visitors to government buildings daily
She vets injured wildlife at the animal rescue center
The clinic vets thousands of pets every year successfully

definitions: exercise one's authority to reject or prohibit a decision or proposal
examples: The president threatened to veto the controversial new legislation
Any member can veto proposals during the committee meetings

definitions: make someone feel annoyed, frustrated, or worried, especially with trivial matters
examples: These minor technical problems continue to vex our team
The unsolved mystery vexed detectives for many years afterward

definitions: create or emit a distinctive emotional atmosphere or feeling
be in harmony or resonate emotionally with someone or something
examples: The band really vibes with the festival crowd perfectly
She vibes positive energy wherever she goes naturally
We immediately vibed when we met at the conference
The decor vibes perfectly with the restaurant's casual concept

definitions: move rapidly and continuously back and forth or side to side
produce or resonate with sound through rapid movement or oscillation
examples: The phone vibrates silently when receiving calls or messages
The washing machine vibrates excessively during the spin cycle
Guitar strings vibrate to produce different musical notes precisely
The speaker cone vibrates creating sound waves in air

definitions: compete eagerly with someone in order to achieve something
examples: Several companies vie for the lucrative government contract annually
Athletes from different nations vie for Olympic gold medals

definitions: look at or inspect something carefully and deliberately
regard or consider in a particular way or from perspective
examples: Thousands of tourists view the famous paintings every year
We viewed several apartments before making our final decision
Management views this proposal as too risky to implement
How do you view the current political situation globally?

definitions: clear someone of blame or suspicion through evidence or argument
show or prove to be right, reasonable, or justified by subsequent events
examples: New evidence completely vindicated the accused man after years
The investigation vindicated her claims of workplace discrimination thoroughly
The successful results vindicated their unconventional research approach completely
History has vindicated his controversial economic policies over time

definitions: break or fail to comply with a rule, law, or formal agreement
treat something sacred with violent disrespect or desecration
examples: The company violated several environmental regulations last year repeatedly
Drivers who violate traffic laws face heavy fines immediately
Vandals violated the cemetery destroying numerous historical gravestones overnight
The invaders violated sacred temples during their brutal conquest

definitions: endorse or mark a passport officially authorizing entry to a country
examples: The embassy will visa your passport within five working days
Immigration officers visa documents at the border crossing daily

definitions: go to see and spend time with someone socially or professionally
access or view a website or online resource through browsing
examples: We visit my grandmother every Sunday for lunch together
The doctor visits patients in their homes when necessary
Millions of users visit the website daily for news updates
Please visit our online store for exclusive special offers

definitions: form a mental image or vision of something not present
make something visible to the eye, especially through graphic representation
examples: Athletes visualize successful performance before competing in major events
Try to visualize your goals to increase motivation significantly
The software visualizes complex data through interactive colorful charts
Scientists visualize molecular structures using advanced computer modeling

definitions: create and publish video blog content on online platforms regularly
examples: She vlogs about her travel adventures every week consistently
Many teenagers vlog their daily routines on social media

definitions: express something in words, especially feelings or opinions publicly
provide the voice for a character in animation or dubbing
examples: Several employees voiced concerns about the new policy changes
She courageously voiced her opposition during the town meeting
Famous actors often voice animated characters in major films
She voices the main character in the popular video game

definitions: empty or remove the contents of something, especially bodily waste
declare that something is legally invalid or null
examples: Patients must void their bladders before the medical procedure
The nurse asked him to void before the examination
The court voided the contract due to fraudulent misrepresentation
The election commission voided hundreds of improperly cast ballots

definitions: hit or kick a ball before it touches the ground
discharge or fire weapons or projectiles in rapid succession
examples: The tennis player volleyed the ball perfectly at the net
She volleyed the soccer ball into the goal brilliantly
The soldiers volleyed shots across the battlefield continuously
Critics volleyed harsh questions at the press conference

definitions: freely offer to do something without being forced or paid
offer information or explanation without being asked directly
examples: Many students volunteer at local hospitals during summer breaks
She volunteers every weekend at the animal shelter downtown
He volunteered the information before anyone could ask questions
No one volunteered an explanation for the strange occurrence

definitions: eject matter from the stomach through the mouth due to illness or disgust
examples: The patient vomited several times after receiving chemotherapy treatment
The rough seas made many passengers vomit during crossing
